title: When will Iran next launch a ballistic missile?
preds:
what a pickle.  
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/09/world/middleeast/us-cautious-on-iran-missile-test-claim.html?_r=0, "outside analysts seemed to have little doubt about what the Iranians launched on Nov. 21".  BUT these analysts are not aware of the political ramifications of such a claim.  Noteworthy, this is not being denied or reported on in Iran, which is off as interest as they normally get pretty uptight on these issues of false accusations, as example http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=251026.  And when they do something they think they are entitled to as October, then they dont deny just say - we are allowed.  More excitement..., can be interpreted and span to suit any argument ... on the basis they did this and now realise it was an error politically as they want no sanctions, moving a bit more to later as not sure if anyone will say this actually happened....
Changing prediction just in case the scorers reject the news about a launch Nov. 21.
Switching back in case the 21st isn't verified.

This question should close soon, retroactive to Nov. 21. Dateline 12-9-15 The United States will investigate (Reuters) reports that Iran launched a ballistic missile last month in violation of UN Security Council resolutions, U.S. Ambassador to the UN Samantha Power said. The move comes as Tehran is close to meeting the conditions (FT) of the July nuclear deal that could lead to the lifting of some international sanctions early next year. Meanwhile, Washington is reportedly helping arrange a deal to send part of Iran's nuclear fuel stockpile to Kazakhstan (WSJ). Daily Brief: Council on Foreign Relations [dailybrief@e.cfr.org]

Renewing old forecast just in case they don't confirm it.
http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1296dad2-9e2e-11e5-b45d-4812f209f861.html#axzz3toh68KGu

This question is done. Brier scores should only be scored up to November 21st (earlier if these earlier launches are confirmed).  *Should note that we'll need final confirmation since the State Department isn't saying anything yet.

This will turn out to be a case where it doesn't matter what's true. It only matters what the paperwork says.  Whether the lads shot off a missile at Chabahar or not, everybody wants a deal so badly they will clear their throats politely and look in some other direction, and the deal will plough ahead.

The US is reviewing reports of the launch of a Ghadr-110 missile from Chabahar near the Pakistani border on 21 Nov., according to Reuters. (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-usa-idUSKBN0TR2G920151208 )

Since the November Launch hasn't closed the bin i am assuming here that we are talking about the NEXT test which i think they will purposely hold just pryor to the National Conventions in hopes of somehow affecting the outcome of hte Presidential election here in the U.S.
Ugh. I increased my pre-March bin to 20% too late (Nov 26th). I guess this will be closed and scored only up until Nov 21st?

Post Mortem: a ballistic missile launch occurred Nov. 21, 2015. News just out. Tal Inbar ‏@inbarspace 18h18 hours ago
Iran tests another mid-range ballistic missile (Ghadr 110) in breach of UN resolutions. The test occurred on Nov. 21 Dateline 12-8-15 http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-idUSKBN0TQ2O220151208 Hint to forecasters: Both the Foreign Policy email alert and Tal Inbar on Twitter predicted this on Nov. 19 and I reported this here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/45589 From now on, if he gives a forecast, I'm going to learn my lesson and bump up to 100%. Instead I was chicken and just went to 70%. Another important lesson: the daily Foreign Policy email alerts have often reported breaking news in a format that makes it far easier to access than web searches. They tend not to miss anything. AL-Monitor's email list also is great, sometimes reports news before Foreign Policy does.

http://www.businessinsider.com/iran-tests-new-ballistic-missile-in-breach-of-un-security-council-2015-12 There's several unknowns here though: a) no official notification to the Security Council, b) whether this actually pre-dates the question open, c) whether this is being confused with the October launch(es), d) whether this was actually a long-range ballistic missile and not something else, etc etc.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-idUSKBN0TQ2O220151207 I wasn't anticipating another test so soon after the one in October, as they have tended to have several months gap between launches and they had one in February too. I'm not sure when if ever they've had three launches within a ten month period. This will be my worst Brier Score since I started GJP, as I had only 5% on this outcome. I'm adjusting my percentages, but that won't matter as this question should close retrospectively.

Moving back to normal stance - the reports say the missile test was on Nov 21, so assuming the question will be closed back to that time, if it closes.  If it doesn't close, then should have a more balanced forecast. Am upping near term a bit because even if this one not corroborated, the risk of an additional test now appears higher.
Still no separate confirmation, but the Fox report sounds plausible. (FWIW the whole issue of what the UN prohibits/will prohibit is a bit muddy).
Good thing I didn't get in on this question until last night
Huh! That test was Nov 21 (therefore, my forecast change is pointless) but not in the region of the NOTAM that there was a flurry about here, if F__x news is to be believed.
Fox News reporting that that Iran fired a second ballistic missile

Yup [1], my Brier score is increasingly פֿאַרקאַקט.  On the other hand I think this proves that GJOpen is not talking to any spooks, because the test happened on November 21st and presumably the spooks knew about it as it happened. [1] http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/12/07/iran-tests-another-mid-range-ballistic-missile-in-breach-un-resolutions.html

Iran wants to be seen as a stabilizing force with ISIS fighting. It also wants to play a political role in the region. It will not risk its standing with other forces in the region until ISIS is destroyed, which won't happen until after 2017
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

This is a heads-up notice to GJ administrators. I'm wondering how you might handle this Question come March 1st. I'm sure there are other questions like this, but this one caught my attention. Similar, in a way, to the WTI question, there will be a category that becomes closed. In this instance, the category will be closed by time. Now, while I would not expect people to be entering new forecasts in expired bins for this question, I do foresee that forecasts of inactive participants will remain. Without spending a lot of time on this, I'm thinking that to score such a question as this properly, you would need a staged approach that is really a function of each period, or something like that ...
About 4 months to the first date, and then the next two intervals are two months long. I think considering the current climate, later seems more likely...
Most likely won't happen in the question's time-frame, but I'm reluctant to completely discount potential actions of reactionaries within Iran.

The 2015 date cited by the U.S. intelligence community has been revised earlier in 2015 to state that Iran will not be able to deploy an operational ICBM until later this decade at the earliest. http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-114hhrg94227/pdf/CHRG-114hhrg94227.pdf The question is when will Iran next launch a ballistic missile, not when will Iran next launch an intercontinental ballistic missile. But given the air around the Iranian nuclear deal it doesn't look like Iran will test even a medium-range ballistic missile in the coming future lest the progress to unwind sanctions built on the fear of its nuclear program be undone.

I was wrong. Why Iran would launch another ballistics missile until sanctions are completely off and  contemplated implementation day. Now with the IAEA conclusion of report on Parchin, strong incentives for Iranians not to launch until July 1, 2016

Moving 5% from Between May and June to July or later, basically for the passage of time. Missile launches are controlled by the hard-line faction in Iran's government, hence much less predictable, as they are not too enthusiastic about the nuclear deal and won't be deterred by the possibility of setting back its implementation.
Looking at Iranian elections in first quarter of 2016, if anything happens should be post elections

(no change, just an observation) Interesting how little rumint there seems to be. Based on the consensus, it looks like most agree that the question involves a new(er) missile, not a run-of-the-mill smaller system in the inventory in a military exercise.
In light of recent events, that some transfer of Russian ballistic missile technology to IR should be considered. Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Nothing came of the aircraft exclusion alert.
I don't think Iran would want to become a bigger issue in the US Presidential Election. If they do, it'll be earlier rather than later.

Is this the best question?   When will a ballistic missile with a nuclear warhead be launched. That involves the nuclear weapon, in warhead form, on a missile.
This will occur after the specified times.

I am increasing my odds for >Jul with the passage of time.  I decided to assume an exponential distribution of delay times, with an average wait of 10 months (the historical wait has been 7.5 months (see @fifty-six's analysis), but Iran might be less willing to launch a missile the potential end of sanctions).   I find the consensus forecast here somewhat wacky.  Based on the consensus, Iran is less likely to launch a missile in the next 3 months then the following 2 months?  This yields an implied rate that is 2 times higher for March-April than now-February.  What is this based on, exactly?
Oil money will start to flow. No need to flex muscles. Only risk is power struggle with Saudi Arabia
Before the October test flight Iran had held off on tests for a while. So, they may have a backlog of testing to do starting in the spring.
following @cmeinel & NOTAM info - but wondering if Tal Inbar has similarly predicted prior tests.

Thanks cmeinel for for the NOTAM!  One minor question for GJI. Everything I remember about previous GJ Iranian missile issues is that it really meant military missiles rather than worrying (too much) about the space launch efforts. (This now seems perhaps at odds with what I remember about the DPRK questions.)

I find it hard to believe that Iran would risk ending of sanctions over a ballistic missile test. However, just in case I'm wrong and Iran's Notice to Airmen near its satellite launch facility means what it seems to mean, raising probability of launch before 1 March. Dateline 11-19-15 Another Iranian missile test? Tal Inbar, head of the Space and UAV Research Center at the Fisher Brothers Institute for  Air and Space Strategic Studies, notes that Iran has issued a Notice to Airmen in a province that's home to Iran's satellite and missile launch site. RT @inbarspace Is an Iranian space launch imminent? NOTAM on Semnan area may suggest launch attempt on Nov 21-23 time period. https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CUIg7oqWIAAhflI.jpg
Situation Report: Foreign Policy [fp@foreignpolicy.com]
Iran risks too much to do something so foolish.
Very business-like photo of MRBM (?) in a cave: http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/18/us-iran-nuclear-iaea-idUSKCN0T72B720151118#KmbkJgCRQCuusCFM.97

There were some comments earlier regarding whether routine military exercises that launched something like SCUD class, FROGs, or MLRS equipment would count for a yes. I believe the question concerns more modern and longer range systems. Looking at the "More Info" it mentions "test" and "testing." I don't believe that one could stretch a FROG launch into a "test" even though it is ballistic and (sort of) guided.

The nuclear material treaty recently negotiated should be approved and in force by March. The treaty does not change the ballistic missile restrictions already in place. Iran will want to see if the UN will become more forceful in enforcing that ban once the nuclear treaty is in place, but before they make any meaningful actions under that treaty.

I think that if Iran is going to launch another missile in the near future, it is going to be sooner rather than later. If they can wait, I think they will wait more than one year. If they can't, then I think they won't wait long.
granularity and logical consistency on 3 last  percentages
The token system was better for this type of prediction
My understanding is they won't be ready before 7/16.

Trend News Agency, November 14, 'Iran discloses range of recently tested ballistic missile': http://en.trend.az/iran/society/2456440.html
Assumes IR has completed evaluation of Emad (v1) test. Assumes incremental improvements to missile design, followed by another test to evaluate (v2). Assumes IRGC administers program ( Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Aerospace Force) and not regular IR military, hence an expedited schedule. 
Affirming forecast.
Iran has Isis to consider now. too much uncertainty exists for them to test "the button"

All of my estimates about Iran are based on the assumption that they are planning to appear well-behaved for the next year or so.  If they're not, I'm wrong about practically everything. Good thing I don't have any money riding on this.

IRGC Commander: Iran's New Long-Range Ballistic Missile Alters Balance
http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13940819000634

a priori : about as likely as not likely for NOT before 1 July 2016 (50%)
rest: a priori chance for # of months
They are waiting until the US presidential election.
Threat of economic sanctions; would cause an uproar.

The Iran agreement does not  cover deployment or tests of ballistic missiles. If Iran  tested the missile after the Iran agreement and before implementation day; Iran will test ballistic missiles at will.
That  is a decision for Khamenei not Roubani. If Irans's experts need another test and have a new prototype to test they will anytime.

"On enemies’ efforts to restrict Iran’s missile program and defense, Shamkhani said that no reduction of Iran’s deterrence capabilities or slowing its pace is acceptable in the view of 37 years of continuous progress in defensive capacities."
http://en.mehrnews.com/news/111848/Vienna-meeting-must-determine-who-is-terrorist
Pretty drastic change of mind. I now think the nuclear deal will have no bearing on the scheduling of the next launch.
Doing this will catalyze world opinion to overthrow the current regime.
Anything could happen, but the frequency hasn't been that high.

Based on the information in the above survey question, I am assuming that the missiles they are concerned with are long to medium range surface to air ballistic missiles capable of nuclear payloads.  The last 3 Iranian ballistic missile test launches of this variety have been launched on August 2012, February 2014 and October 2015 as per http://www.iranwatch.org/our-publications/weapon-program-background-report/iran-missile-milestones-1985-2014 We can calculate the amount of months between launches by the following:   
Aug 2012 to Feb 2014 = 18 months
Feb 2014 to Oct 2015 = 20 months
October 2015 to X = 16 to 22 months
I'm using a range of 16 to 22 months based on an average of 19 months with a tight standard deviation. We solve for X which is an upcoming launch date range from February 2017 to August 2017.
I expect there will be another launch very soon after the nuclear deal is finalized.
There would be no benefit of Iranian conducting any tests if the deal is on track

Iran has a fairly advanced rocket propulsion capability testing regularly since 2008, now given their nuclear deal being signed and waiting implementation, its likely they may show some restraint.
http://www.spacelaunchreport.com/safir.html
Iran is happy about nuclear agreement & will not provoke international community prior to lifting of sanctions.
Apparently, there are no reasons to tighten relations with United States and  partners, even in the light of agreement on nuclear,
The tests serve only to grab attention.  Right now, and through the spring and early summer, I doubt Iran will need to draw attention to itself or the region.
They will wait to influence the US presidential race.
The treaty has been signed, so go ahead & launch.
Adjusting for passage of time (and no apparent narrative).

WSJ, November 5: 'After Nuclear Deal, Iran’s Hard-liners Assert Power': http://www.wsj.com/articles/after-nuclear-deal-irans-hard-liners-assert-power-1446732775
Radio Free Europe, November 6: 'Iran Bans Import, Distribution Of U.S. Goods': http://www.rferl.org/content/iran-united-states-ban-consumer-goods/27347721.html
IBT, November 4: 'Iranian Airline Violates Terms Of Nuclear Deal By Purchasing Planes To Use In Syrian War': http://www.ibtimes.com/iranian-airline-violates-terms-nuclear-deal-purchasing-planes-use-syrian-war-2169855
The Guardian, November 5: 'Iran military hackers target Obama administration accounts – report': http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/05/iran-revolutionary-guard-hacking-obama-administration
Bloomberg, November 4: 'Iran and Saudi Arabia Clash Inside Syria Talks': http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2015-11-04/iran-and-saudi-arabia-clash-inside-syria-talks It appears the hardliners have come back with a vengeance in the wake of the nuclear deal with the West. IR had successfully tested a cruise missile and medium-range ballistic missile this year. They may also have in development a S-300 variant: 'Iran to Build Own Missile Defense Based on Knockoff of Russia’s S-300': http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20151020/1028799803/iran-missile-defense-analogue.html I believe the Iranians will pause to evaluate downrange data from the October test. However, their deepening involvement in the Syrian war leads me to also believe that the cycle between tests will be shorter:
Reuters, November 4: 'Iran's defense hawks prepare for worst after nuclear deal': http://news.yahoo.com/irans-defense-hawks-prepare-worst-nuclear-deal-121419729.html
Iran will not lunch any missile until things settle down in the Mideast and they are winning the war with ISIS. They will launch in 2017.
Following fifty-sixty's analysis, the statistical data seems to suggest 50% for pre-March, 12.5% for March+April, 12.5% for May+June, and 25% for July or later.  I'm going to go with those numbers.

Following wisdom of the crowd.  Suspect the October launch, made Iran's point.  As long as there is no serious challenge to Iran due to the prior launch, it would not seem like a priority for a second lauch (unless there are scheduled development programs ongoing). Giving equal weight, but first bucket is 4 months, compared to 2 months for the other two.
fifty-sixty's comment & the fact that will have plenty of time to pile more into the long bins. Plus lack of  personal insight, therefore hedging.
For a while, the Iranians should play friends.

I suspect this was a concession to hard-liners following the approval of the JCPOA, and Iran can get away with this once. If they have any further tests prior to Implementation Day, it will (at a minimum) delay the lifting of sanctions. Leaving some room for tests that follow a very early Implementation Day.
As US and allies are working with Iran in getting a deal, they will wait to launch another.
Iran has to wait for the sanctions to be gone or close too

For all the noise the Supreme Leader makes against the west he too would not want to rub the west in the wrong way. Especially now that the region is extremely unstable. With the falling oil prices and ISIS at its doorstep it would hurt Iran to test the patience of the west at this critical juncture. Most of the propaganda by the Supreme Leader is aimed at pleasing the conservative sections of society. It seems there is an understanding that the Supreme Leader speaks about Islamic values and Western evils while the President opines that integrating with the west is also a possibility. Its a good cop bad cop routine that hopefully should work in the near term
There is a thawing in relations with the West, and belligerence of this type would not serve Iran's rational self-interest at present.

No reason why they will not do it. They did it 8 days before "adoption day" (when all western world thought they have too much in stake to take such risks), they will do it again, whenever they like. Pure timing question. When? During last 10 years there has been (at least) 16-17 separate occasions (as listed in  "Iran Missile Milestones: 1985-2014"). 
http://www.iranwatch.org/our-publications/weapon-program-background-report/iran-missile-milestones-1985-2014
Longest delay has been 20 months, shortest less than a month. Average delay around 7-8 months places new date somewhere in May 2016, median delay 4-5 months - in February. 8 of the delays have been less than 5 months, 4 more than 9 months. So we might say that pure statistical probabilities are roughly 50% for pre-March and 25% for post-July. (These calculations are really rough and likely incorrect, no good data) Several reasons to think it will happen rather sooner than later. Most of them are hard to quantify, but one is enough. Looks like preparations for next major "Great Prophet" war games are ongoing. Historically at least 7 out of 9 of these have featured some ballistic tests. "The Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC) naval forces is going to hold a major military exercise in coming months"
"will be held in the current Iranian year, which will end on March 19, 2016."
"Back in February, the IRGC staged massive naval exercises, codenamed the Great Prophet-9 /.../ The IRGC also fired a number of “Persian Gulf” ballistic missiles"
http://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2015/10/18/891905/irgc-to-stage-massive-naval-drill Translated into numbers gives us about 70-80% that the tests will happen before March 19. Adding personal bias.

Iran's missile program is under the control of the Revolutionary Guards and conservative elements of the hierarchy. Iran has also very clearly stated that the current nuclear deal does not restrict their missile program. They will therefore want to keep emphasizing that point with launches. On the other hand, they have already done so with a launch in October, and may not feel the need to do so again for some time. Historically, test launches have tended to be a little more than once a year, and there have been at least two in 2015 already (there was one in February 2015). I don't think they'd go to the extent of a launch with a view to affecting the 26 February 2016 elections, so I wouldn't expect anything before 01 March 2016.  I would give most weight to no launches in the next 8 months i.e. not before 01 July 2016, especially as this is also the period when sanctions should be in the process of being lifted. Only fringe elements would want to sabotage this process, especially when the Supreme Leader has given it his blessing. However, I'm allocating some chance to launches in this period, for the IRG etc to continue to demonstrate the independence of their missiles from the nuclear program. Chances of a launch may also increase if lifting of sanctions is obstructed for any reason.
Doesn't seem likely before "implementation day," not sure it is a priority, and don't seem to be all that frequent.  But, not completely certain here.

Either before the elections or after implementation day. (FWIW any decision may be made based on either political decisions that one might reasonably guess or programmatic issues which may be very opaque.)  There are also ranges of ballistic missiles (no intended pun); wish the question specified MRBM or something.  Also separate from any UN sanctions on Iran there is the MTCR which (sort of) controls some technology: http://www.mtcr.info/english/
To show that they are still a power to be reckoned with in spite of the nuclear treaty
this is the "face saving" gesture Iran gives to its own people, and a shaking fist toward the West.
They like to keep the U.S. off balance.
They won't want to stir the pot this early on since the deal.
Following Manfred, 000,  and JP's excellent link and analysis.
Missile launches of any type do not seem to be a priority.  There are more important things to finish so that sanctions can be removed and the economy start to improve.
Iran's hands will be full in syria until then

The JCPOA only restricts ballistic missiles that can carry nuclear warheads --- Specifically, Annex B of the new resolution calls upon Iran “not to undertake any activity related to ballistic missiles designed to be capable of delivering nuclear weapons, including launches using such ballistic missile technology.”  However, it doesn't preclude non-nuclear missile tests.  Historically, Iran has not shown a great interest in ballistic missile testing. It certainly would complicate matters if they launched any ballistic missle. It would give opponents to JCPOA an opening to say that the missiles could carry nuclear warheads and thereby stall the release from sanctions. At this point, since Iran seems to be pursuing progress on the JCPOA, it would seem stupid to work against themselves by undercutting the lifting of sanctions as soon as possible. https://www.armscontrol.org/Issue-Briefs/2015-07-27/Addressing-Irans-Ballistic-Missiles-in-the-JCPOA-and-UNSC-Resolution

The recent launch has likely satisfied their requirements for a while.  Some chance they could launch again next summer if they need to test technical improvements, though they'd probably want some European and Chinese cash flowing into the economy before antagonising their negotiating partners

Iran is very interested in make  the nuclear agreement works so they won't look for provocations with the international community. Only if we can see more violence in Yemen and Siria can make  annoucements to Saudi Arabia.

Only 10% BEFORE July 1st, 2016...and...only if to save face in the world's eyes that they deserve a seat at the "big" table. They do NOT want any second thoughts when it comes to releasing the sanctions that have been applied.

Google doesn't bring up any good listing of Iran missile launches.  Anybody?  From Wikipedia I'd guess a rate of once or twice a year.  They snuck this one in before the nuclear signing but I think they'd wait until they got SWIFT back to launch another, plus they are pretty busy in Syria and Iraq and Yemen right now, so maybe might not want to waste the money.
Will happen soon, they're working on improving chances of success
They will need to do this some time fairly soon to show they haven't caved in completely, but the sanctions-related issues will need to get sorted first.
If they are going to do it, it will be sooner rather than later, but probably won't do it.

Missile testing would imply preparations for the ability to project nuclear weapons across a distance.  It would work against Iran's own interests in having sanctions lifted to imply it is getting close to becoming a nuclear capable state.
